awd_titl_txt: CoPe Conference: Evaluating Land Use Tradeoffs Due to Sea Level Rise in the Chesapeake Bay: Hampton, Va - June 2020/ Salisbury, MD - October 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chesapeake Bay (CB) coastal region has one of the highest rates of sea level rise in the United States. Homes, ecosystems, and millions of dollars of critical infrastructure are increasingly at risk of erosion,and various types of flooding. In order for CB communities to plan for the future, members must understand their local rates of sea level rise (RSLR) and the factors contributing to these local variations. A significant contributor to differences in RSLR is that land surrounding the CB is sinking (i.e. vertical
land motion (VLM)) at different rates, but the causes behind these rates are not easily measured or widely understood. Scientists, town planners, and land managers must discuss the current science of VLM, how to monitor its rates across the CB, and possible mitigation strategies. Furthermore, scientists and a wide range of community stakeholders, including those in underrepresented rural areas, should understand how RSLR will have multiple impacts on residential communities, wetlands, and agriculture. They each have their own priorities that will influence what management options are most ecologically, socially, and economically desirable or feasible. Presenting the latest science on the causes of RSLR, anticipated land use changes, and the cost-effectiveness of different management options will empower the CB region and others facing similar threats from RSLR.

The team will convene two workshops: 1) Vertical Land Motion in the Chesapeake Bay, and 2) Evaluating Land Use Tradeoffs in the Chesapeake Bay. Workshop 1 will improve scientific understanding of the physical drivers of VLM rates in the CB and identify areas where understanding VLM rates may be most critical for land use planning. Workshop 2 will focus on how to effectively communicate VLM science and how rates of RSLR will cause land use changes and affect coastal communities. The goals of the workshops are to: 1) understand and disseminate the state of the science on VLM; 2) improve stakeholder understanding of accelerated RSLR; 3) learn how RSLR may change current land use practices, and 4)engage stakeholders throughout the workshop process. The workshop schedules involve: a) pre-workshop planning; b) holding workshop 1 c) workshop 1 synthesis and outcomes analysis; d) holding workshop 2; and e) a synthesis report and information distribution. Participants will include researchers, land conservationists, agricultural specialists, town planners, and community members, especially from underserved communities. At the end of these workshops there will be better information for use in community decision-making. Workshop organizers will assess how priorities differ among stakeholders and what factors most influence stakeholders' actions, which will guide selection of the research, tools, and outreach communities need to effectively plan for sea level rise.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Chesapeake Bay (CB) coastal region has one of the highest rates of relative sea level rise (RSLR) in the United States. Homes, ecosystems, and millions of dollars of critical infrastructure are increasingly at risk of inundation. To help CB communities plan for the future, community members must understand their local rates of RSLR and the factors contributing to these local variations. Researchers and policy-makers must also understand how persons living and working on the coast make decisions on how to deal with RSLR impacts. Maryland Sea Grant hosted two workshops to bring together scientists and those making decisions about RSLR in order to better understand and prepare for flooding impacts.

First, Maryland Sea Grant hosted a one-day workshop on February 28, 2020 for subject experts, town planners, land managers, and educators to discuss how land sinking in the CB region (i.e. vertical land motion (VLM)) may contribute to differences in RSLR rates around the Bay. The scientists presented on the processes that cause land to subside, how VLM is measured, and the affects that has how we plan for RSLR. As a group, we then discussed the best way to communicate this science to the community and where we need more research. Recommendations included: Increase monitoring of VLM throughout the region; better distinguish causes of subsidence (e.g. human activities, natural processes); convey information on ways to reduce land sinking rates; and keep collaborating across different disciplines and organizations to share information and work towards solutions.

Secondly, we had a series of three 90-minute virtual workshops between December 2020 – March 2021 to learn if farmers and woodlot owners around the Chesapeake and coastal bays are experiencing increasing rates of flooding and salty conditions on their land and how they plan respond to these changing conditions. We presented the latest science on the causes of RSLR, how the land is expected to change (e.g. it is harder to grow crops where saltwater has made the ground saturated and salty and more favorable to wetland plant growth), and the cost-effectiveness of different management options (e.g. trying to drain the field, changing to a different crop, allowing wetlands to establish). Each farmer or woodlot owner had their own priorities, which influenced the management options they thought most desirable or feasible. We learned that while some producers plan to try to protect their farms and/or woodlots from RSLR in the short term, in the long term the majority of them plan to change their land use practices in response to RSLR. Results from the workshop suggest a need to investigate : 1) better ways to assess the farms or woodlots soil and water conditions; and 2) new crop varieties or technologies to help farmers adapt their lands to be productive under wetter and saltier conditions. We also suggest that policy-makers seek ways to assist farmers/woodlot owners wanting protect their lands (e.g. financial aid for tide gates or living shorelines) or transition their lands to different uses (e.g. better designed conservation easement programs or carbon credits). We hope to continue this work to better plan for farmland adaptation to accelerating RSLR rates.
